metadata.titleEn: ChinaHighCO: High-resolution and High-quality Ground-level CO dataset for China (2013-2023)
metadata.description: ChinaHighCO is one of the series of long-term, full-coverage, high-resolution, and high-quality datasets of ground-level air pollutants for China (i.e., ChinaHighAirPollutants, CHAP). It is generated from the big data (e.g., ground-based measurements, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulations) using artificial intelligence by considering the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. This is the big data-derived seamless (spatial coverage = 100%) daily, monthly, and yearly 1 km (i.e., D1K, M1K, and Y1K) ground-level CO dataset in China from 2013 to present. Note that this dataset is 10 km before 2019, and improved to 1 km after 2019. This dataset yields a high quality with a cross-validation coefficient of determination (CV-R2) value of 0.80, and an root-mean-square error (RMSE) values of 0.29 mg m-3 for the daily retrievals, respectively. Note that this dataset is continuously updated, and if you want to apply for more data or have any questions, please contact me (Email: weijing_rs@163.com; weijing@umd.edu). The data file contains four codes (Python, Matlab, IDL and R language) nc2geotiff codes for NC to GeoTiff.
metadata.instructions: File Name: The data is stored in the NetCDF file format, and the file name is CHAP_CO_ab_yyyymmdd_V1.nc, where a represents time resolution (D represents daily data, M represents monthly data, Y represents annual data), b represents spatial resolution (1K represents 1km), yyyy represents year, mm represents month, and dd represents day. Data reading method: Python, Matlab, IDL, and other programming methods can be used to convert files from NC to TIF. The data coordinate system is WGS-1984, with a background value of 65535.

literatureList.titleEn: Ground-level gaseous pollutants (NO2, SO2, and CO) in China: daily seamless mapping and spatiotemporal variations
literatureList.referenceEn: Wei, J., Li, Z., Wang, J., Li, C., Gupta, P., & Cribb, M. (2023). Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of datasets that utilize artificial intelligence to account for the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution?
Feature Specification.Answer: integrates various data sources, high spatial resolution, temporal resolution, coefficient of determination (R2), root mean square error (RMSE)

Quantification.Question: What is the temporal resolution of the ground-level CO data collected in China between 2013 and 2023?

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors have contributed to the development of high-resolution ground-level CO datasets in China over the past decade?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The development of high-resolution ground-level CO datasets in China over the past decade has been facilitated by the use of artificial intelligence technology, which accounts for the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. The integration of large datasets from sources such as ground-based observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulation data has also been crucial. These methods have enabled the creation of seamless national CO data with an R2 of 0.80 and an RMSE of 0.29 mg/m3, with spatial resolution improving from 10 km to 1 km since 2019.

Causal Consequence.Question: What is the impact on the accuracy of ground-level CO concentration estimations when artificial intelligence is utilized to integrate diverse data sources such as ground observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of artificial intelligence to integrate diverse data sources for estimating ground-level CO concentrations results in a high accuracy, as evidenced by a cross-validation coefficient of determination (R2) of 0.80 and a root mean square error (RMSE) of 0.29 mg/m3.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the purpose of employing artificial intelligence to account for spatiotemporal heterogeneity in air pollution data collection across China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The purpose of employing artificial intelligence is to consider the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution and generate high-resolution, high-quality ground-level CO data seamlessly across China from 2013 to present, using various data sources such as ground-based observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulation data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies and technologies are used to collect and process high-resolution CO data across China, considering factors like temporal and spatial heterogeneity of air pollution?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The methodologies involve utilizing artificial intelligence techniques to account for the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. The data collection uses large datasets from ground-based observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulation data to produce seamless ground CO data from 2013 to the present across China. The spatial resolution is 10 km before 2019 and 1 km after 2019, with temporal resolutions at daily, monthly, and annual levels.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements and data sources enable the creation of high-resolution, high-quality surface-level CO datasets across China from 2013 to present?
Enablement.Answer: The creation of high-resolution, high-quality surface-level CO datasets is enabled by artificial intelligence technologies that account for the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. These datasets are derived from large-scale data sources, including ground-based observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulation data.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the data collection methods used to generate a dataset of ground-level CO concentrations in China from 2013 to the present, focusing on the integration of AI technologies and big data sources.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods involve utilizing artificial intelligence technologies to account for the spatiotemporal heterogeneity of air pollution. The dataset is produced from big data sources, including ground-based observations, satellite remote sensing products, atmospheric reanalysis, and model simulation data, providing seamless ground-level CO data across China from 2013 onwards.
